questions.explanation: “Ibowofagba”—the proper display of deference—is also known as “iteriba” in Yoruba, emphasizing respect and humility.
questions.questionText: (1) ORUKO MIIRAN FUN IBOWOFAGBA NI___

questions.explanation: “Ise ajumose ilu” refers to the civic or communal work carried out by the people; hence it is simply called “ise ilu” (the work of the town).
questions.questionText: (2) ISE AJUMOSE ILU NI___

questions.explanation: The proverb points to how a pretence or laziness (“opuro”) can delude one’s heart about genuine work.
questions.questionText: (3) _______ LO SE FI OKAN TAN LENU ISE?

questions.explanation: A person of genuine character (omoluabi) does not need to pay “owo ori” in public—his respect is inherent.
questions.questionText: (4) OMOLUABI A MAA SAN OWO ORI NI AWUJO?

questions.explanation: In the absence of law, the spread of “irẹbo” (corruption/immorality) increases, leading to more wicked behavior in society.
questions.questionText: (5) IPA WO NI AIPA-OFIN MO KO NINU IWA IBAJE TIO TUBO N GBOORO SI LAWUJO W,

questions.explanation: Traditionally, the “Olowa” is appointed to proclaim messages throughout the town in the Yoruba system of government.
questions.questionText: (6) NINU ASA ISEJOBA ILE YORUBA, TANI O MAAN KEDE KAAKIRI ILU?

questions.explanation: Apart from “baale,” the head of a council may also be called “adari,” indicating one who leads and oversees communal affairs.
questions.questionText: (7) YATO SI BAALE, ORUKO MIRAN TI A TUN LEE FUN OLORI AGBOOLE NI ___

questions.explanation: The chieftaincy title “oye atojuran” is typically associated with the palace (“aafin”), highlighting the holder’s central role in palace matters.
questions.questionText: (8) OYE ATOJURAN NI OYE TI O JE ___

questions.explanation: The “parakoyi” is the designated collector of levies from those reluctant to contribute, ensuring that communal dues are gathered.
questions.questionText: (9) OKAN NINU AWON WONYI NI O MAAN SAAJU LATI GBA ISAKOLE AWON IRUKEREJE TI O BA WA NI AYIKA ILU?

questions.explanation: Yoruba tradition generally holds that a chief (oloye) should not accumulate several chieftaincy titles in one town so as not to dilute the dignity of each title.
questions.questionText: (10) NJE OLOYE LEE JU MEJI TABI META LO NI ADUGBO KAN?

questions.explanation: The primary duty of a Balogun (war chief) is to “ja ogu” (fight the enemy), underscoring his martial responsibility.
questions.questionText: (11) ISE BALOGUN NI KI O ___

questions.explanation: The elders (ogboni) are customarily granted the privilege of surveying the “odi ilu” (the town’s periphery) to assess communal well‐being.
questions.questionText: (12) AWON OGBONI ILU NI ANFAANI LATI WO ___

questions.explanation: “Otun” literally means “the second” and designates the deputy or second in command in the palace.
questions.questionText: (13) ____ NI IGBAKEJI OBA NI AAFIN?

questions.explanation: The title “iyalode” is one of the highest among the “oye ifidanilola,” symbolizing the esteemed status of women in the community.
questions.questionText: (14) OKAN LARA OYE IFIDANILOLA NI IWONYI AYAFI?

questions.explanation: In Yoruba tradition, the leader of the town’s women is honored with the title “iyalode”.
questions.questionText: (15) OLORI AWON OBINRIN ILU NI ___?

questions.explanation: The poem serves as a cautionary message with warnings and moral lessons—thus it is classified as “ewi ikilo” (warning poetry).
questions.questionText: (16) IRU EWI WO NI EYI?

questions.explanation: The poet’s admonitions are addressed to “eniyan” (all people), urging everyone to be mindful of their conduct.
questions.questionText: (17) TANI AKEWI N KILO FUN?

questions.explanation: The poet stresses the power of the “ipe” (the call or summons) as central to urging responsibility—linking it to the characterization in the poem.
questions.questionText: (18) KINI OMO OWENEWENE GEGE BI AKEWI SE SO NINU EWI YII?

questions.explanation: Counting the lines in the poem shows there are 12 lines—in Yoruba, “méjìlà” means twelve.
questions.questionText: (19) ILA MELO NI GBOGBO EWI NAA?

questions.explanation: The poem implies that the one who truly upholds truth (“asotito”) is the exalted or high one—symbolized by “oke.”
questions.questionText: (20) TANI N BE LEYIN ASOTITO?

questions.explanation: “Ọrẹ̀ Ọdàlẹ̀” suitably encapsulates the critical tone of the passage that exposes the degenerative nature of irresponsible wealth.
questions.questionText: (21) AKỌ́RÍ TÁBÌ AKỌ́LẸ̀ TÍ Ó BÁ ÀYỌKÀ MÚ JÚLỌ́ NI ______?

questions.explanation: The text suggests that instead of extravagant spending, the wisdom found in proverbs (“òwè”) should serve as the true exemplar.
questions.questionText: (22) KÁKÀ KÁ FÓWÓ ỌLÁ LẸ̀LẸ̀ PÍPẸ̀LẸ̀ LỌ́ TÚN PẸ̀LẸ̀ ṢÍ JE ÀPÈẸRẸ ___?

questions.explanation: The passage implies a tripartite participation—a common motif in Yoruba thought—so “mẹ́tà” (three) is indicated.
questions.questionText: (23) ÀWỌN MÉLÒÓ NÍ WỌN KÓPÁ NÍNÚ ÈRÈ NÁÁ ___?

questions.explanation: In English usage, a private or pleasure vehicle is simply called a “car,” matching the Yoruba term “ọkọ̀ ayọkẹ́lẹ́.”
questions.questionText: (24) ORÚKỌ TÍ A LÉÈ FÚN Ọ̀KỌ̀ AYỌ̀KẸ́LẸ́ NÍ ÈDÈ GẸ̀Ẹ̀SÍ NI___?

questions.explanation: The proverb teaches that a wealthy person (owólábí) typically has but one true friend.
questions.questionText: (25) ÀWỌN MÉLÒÓ NÍ Ọ̀RẸ̀ OWÓLÁBÍ?

questions.explanation: A connecting word or conjunction in Yoruba is called “òrò àsọ̀pọ̀” because it binds two phrases or ideas together.
questions.questionText: (26) ÒRỌ̀ TÍ Ó LÉÈ SỌ ÒRỌ̀ MÉJÌ PỌ̀ NÍ ÀN PẸ̀NÍ ___?

questions.explanation: In the sentence, two action words (“je” and “mu”) appear; thus, there are “meji” (two) work‐related verbs.
questions.questionText: (27) BOLA JE EJA ARO, O SI MU OMI TUTU LEE. ORO ISE TI A LEE RI NINU GBOLOHUN YII JE ___?

questions.explanation: This phrase describes nonverbal communication—that is, conveying messages through body language.

options.A: ONA IBARA ENI SORO LAILO OHUN ENU
options.B: ONA IBARA ENI SORO LONA EYA ARA

questions.questionText: (28) LILO EYA ARA WA LATI BA ARA WA SORO NI A N PE NI ____?

questions.explanation: In English punctuation, the symbol used to denote a question is the question mark.
questions.questionText: (29) AMI TI A MAA FI N SE IBERE NI WON PE NI ____ NI EDE GEESI ?

questions.explanation: In discussing money (“owo”), one alternative term is “owo ile,” which stresses its domestic or familiar nature.
questions.questionText: (30) NINU AKAYE OWO EYIN, ORUKO MIRAN TI A TUN LEE FUN OWO EYIN ____ AYAAFI?

questions.explanation: The phrase “ó púró” is used to express that someone is being insincere or dismissive when snubbing another in conversation.
questions.questionText: (31) BI ENIYAN BA YIN IMU SI ENIYAN NIGBA TI O SORO TAN, ITUMO EYI NI ____?

questions.explanation: The marks that appear at the beginning, middle, and end of sentences are punctuation marks—here rendered in Yoruba as “pontu eson.”
questions.questionText: (32) AWON AMI TI A N FI SI ORI ORO, ISALE ORO ATI IPARI ORO NI A N PE NI ____?

questions.explanation: The poetic structure indicates that three (“meta”) endorsements or supports are used, echoing the Yoruba appreciation for triadic completeness.
questions.questionText: (33) NINU AWORAN EWI IGBEYIN AWON OLOSA TI A KA NI SAA YII, AWON MELOO NI WON FI EYIN WON TI AGBA?

questions.explanation: The speaker indicates participation in a narrative recitation—a form best described as “aroko asotan.”
questions.questionText: (34) MO FI ARA MO ATI MI O FI ARA MO A MAA JEYO NINU AROKO ____?

questions.explanation: When speaking about rice (“iresi”), the natural verb is “je” (to eat); thus, Kola “je” his rice at the place of expenditure.
questions.questionText: (35) KOLA _____ IRESI NI IBI INAWO NI ANA?

questions.explanation: In a market setting, people “ra” (buy) goods; hence, they are buying in the town along the market road.
questions.questionText: (36) WON N _____ ILU NI ONA OJA NI AARO YI?

questions.explanation: After his meal, Bola naturally drinks “omi” (water).
questions.questionText: (37) BOLA MU _____ LEYIN IGBA TO JE OUNJE RE TAN

questions.explanation: The context implies a modest or succinct action; “kuru” (meaning brief or limited) best fits the expression.
questions.questionText: (38) KEMI _______ FIOFIO

questions.explanation: “Egba” is a food item; thus, Tunde “je” (ate) it when serving his parents.
questions.questionText: (39) TUNDE _____ EGBA NIGBA TI O SE AWON OBI RE?

questions.explanation: A word that names people, animals, things, and places is a noun—that is, “òrò orúkọ.”
questions.questionText: (40) _____ NI ORO TI O N TOKA SI ORUKO ENIYAN, ERANKO, NNKAN ATI IBIKAN

questions.explanation: For clarity in writing, one must avoid “oro atokun” (extraneous or superfluous words) in a sentence.
questions.questionText: (41) KO SE E MA N ___ NINU GBOLOHUN

questions.explanation: Filler words (“oro atokun”) serve to attach extra emphasis or smoothness to a sentence—that is, they “pon” (stick) to the sentence.

options.B: ORO PON KAN LE NINU GBOLOHUN
options.D: A MAA YAN ORO NINU GBOLOHUN

questions.questionText: (42) ORO ATOKUN A MAA SO NIPA ____?

questions.explanation: A noun that groups or collects names is called a “oro aro-po oruko” (a collective noun).
questions.questionText: (43) IRUFE ORO ORUKO TI O N YAN ORO ORUKO EGBE RE NI WON N PE NI ____?

questions.explanation: A word that substitutes for a noun is a pronoun, known in Yoruba as “oro eyan.”
questions.questionText: (44) ORO TI A LEE LO DIPO ORO ORUKO NINU GBOLOHUN NI ____?

questions.explanation: “Ise abinibi” refers to the inherited or destiny work passed down by one’s forefathers.
questions.questionText: (45) _____ NI ISE TI A JOGUN BA LOWO AWON BABANLA WA?

questions.explanation: In traditional Yoruba society, wisdom is transmitted through proverbs (“òwè”), narrative forms (“àrokodòkò”), and communal assemblies (“àjọ”).
questions.questionText: (46) AWON ONA IRAN ARA ENI LOWO NI IWONI AYAAFI _____?

questions.explanation: There are traditionally three (“meta”) recognized types of agricultural practice or “agbe” in Yoruba agrarian life.
questions.questionText: (47) ORISI AGBE TI A NI JE _____?

questions.explanation: A classic example of an inherited occupation is participation in governance (“ise ijoba”), a role passed through generations.
questions.questionText: (48) APEERE AWON ISE ABINIBI _____?

questions.explanation: The title “alayán” is given to the person who is acknowledged as the pioneer or first entrant into a town.
questions.questionText: (49) ORUKO ENI TI O KOKO LU ILU NI ILE YORUBA NI ____?

questions.explanation: In the proverb, “akoní” is used to describe those who habitually carry burdens—reflecting their role as porters in the community.
questions.questionText: (50) AWON TI WON MAA N KO ENIYAN NI ERU ATI ERU NI WON PE NI ____?

questions.explanation: Supporting one another means keeping confidences—“bó ènì ní àṣírí” (to keep someone’s secret).
questions.questionText: (51) ONA IRAN ARA ENI LOWO A MAA ____?

questions.explanation: Among the options, “òwè” (proverbs) do not directly denote mutual assistance, unlike the other forms that imply collective support.
questions.questionText: (52) EWO NINU AWON WONYI NI KO PON DANDAN ATI DA PADA TI AWON ENIYAN BA RAN ENIYAN LOWO

questions.explanation: Yoruba tradition recognizes Odùduwà as the progenitor—the founding ancestor of the Yoruba people.
questions.questionText: (53) BABANLA AWON YORUBA NI ____?

questions.explanation: The traditional armaments used in Yoruba warfare include a gun (íbọn), sword (àdá), spear (òbẹ), shield (ègbè), and a type of dagger (kánákọ).

options.A: IBON, ADA, OBE, EGBE ATI KANAKO
options.B: ILU, AAKE, KUMO AYETA ATI OFA
options.D: BANTE, IWE, OFA, BATA ATI OUNJE

questions.questionText: (54) LARA AWON OHUN ELO OGUN JIJA NI IWONI AYAAFI ____?

questions.explanation: In Yoruba, the morning (“owuro”) greeting is “Ẹ káàárọ̀.”
The appropriate greeting during the afternoon (“òsán”) is “Ẹ káàsán.”
“Iyaleta” (the later part of the day) is customarily greeted with “Ẹ káalẹ́” (good evening).
“Àárọ̀” also designates the morning period, so the greeting remains “Ẹ káàárọ̀.”
At “àsálẹ̀” (early evening), it is customary to say “Ẹ káalẹ́.”
In the night (“alẹ́”), the greeting “Ẹ káalẹ́” is still used, reflecting continuity in Yoruba salutations.
